content.webTitle: Cast members play a blinder in EastEnders' Live Week climax

fields.headline: Cast members play a blinder in EastEnders' Live Week climax
fields.bodyText: “It just happened.” As explanations for killing your stepdaughter go, Jane’s was at the unconvincing end of the spectrum. Yes, Lucy might have been a drug-hoovering, perma-shagging pain in the rear end, but that was no reason to snuff her out in her prime. So it’s no surprise that even a pair of numpties like Ian and Peter soon realised that Jane was covering for lil’ Bobby Beale, who’d battered his stepsister with a jewellery box. Who says playing Minecraft doesn’t build up those muscles, eh? The Beales were immersed in their faaaa-mily drama while Mick and Nancy were having a moment of father-daughter bonding of their own, figuring out how to dispose of Dean’s body. Spangly Linda was in full poodle mode, proposing to the love of her life in front of a packed Queen Vic, oblivious to the fact that he’d just bumped off her rapist in the beer cellar. Every cast member played a blinder, so much so that you could forget the whole episode was live and just concentrate on their pure misery. The daddy of the night was Ian (Adam Woodyatt), who swung from smashing up plates like he was holding a Greek wedding in the Beales’ kitchen to throwing up (something of a trademark of these live scenes) and then pulling his family together to cover for Bobby. Little minx Cindy had never really had the chance to make anyone warm to her until tonight, but as she read out Lucy’s last letter to her dad she broke the whole family and indeed the nation. What should have ended in tears over Ian’s grief-stricken face at that moment strangely descended into a cheesy, frothing firework display in the Square, complete with Guetta-ised soundtrack. The cast breathed a sigh of relief, but anyone watching was still dwelling on Lucy’s last hours. But at least it provided a backdrop to a beautiful bromantic interlude for Mick and Ian. “You alright?” shouted Mick, over the fireworks as Phil shuffled furtively in the background. “We will be,” replied Ian, in a way that suggested it might all be forgotten by next week. Cynics might argue that making Bobby the murderer was an anticlimax, especially if the Beales get away with sweeping it under the carpet, but there was so much more to Live Week than that. For the fans, it was everything it should have been, with birth, death, marriage and a whole lot of humour. Loyal viewers were rewarded with beautiful details, from the homage to ’Enders’ first ever scene with the discovery of Nick Cotton’s body, to Sonya’s nod to her own Queen Vic delivery and of course Mick’s “Get outta my pub.” The music for the first two episodes was strictly 1985 and the closing scenes of the live extravaganza paid tribute to the show’s creators with the Julia and Tony graffiti. Through the darkness, there were flashes of humour, thanks to Kat’s cake fight, the tease of Ian in a kilt and the look on Jo Joyner’s face when she uttered the internet-breaking line: “How’s Adam?” EastEnders comes out of Live Week on top form, with a some very dangly loose ends to grab on to and some proper naughty tricks up its sleeve.
